message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden loss of vision accompanied by severe posterior headache suggests a posterior cerebral artery (PCA) stroke. The fact that a noncontrast CT of the head showed no evidence of hemorrhagic stroke also supports this diagnosis. Vertebrobasilar stroke and subarachnoid hemorrhage would usually present with different symptoms than those described, and middle cerebral artery stroke usually does not involve vision loss.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden loss of vision, severe posterior headache, and inability to recognize someone are all suggestive of a posterior cerebral artery stroke. The noncontrast CT ruling out a hemorrhagic stroke supports this diagnosis. The other options may present with different symptoms or have different risk factors.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden loss of vision and severe posterior headache suggest a diagnosis of posterior cerebral artery stroke. The fact that there is no evidence of hemorrhagic stroke on the CT scan strengthens this diagnosis. Loss of recognition of a family member also suggests a posterior cerebral artery stroke, as this area of the brain is responsible for visual recognition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden loss of vision, severe posterior headache, and inability to recognize someone suggest that this is a posterior cerebral artery stroke, which is known to cause visual disturbances and can be accompanied by headache. The noncontrast CT scan ruled out hemorrhagic stroke, and the absence of other symptoms such as weakness or numbness makes middle cerebral and vertebrobasilar strokes less likely. Subarachnoid hemorrhage can cause a sudden headache but is not typically associated with visual disturbances.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a sudden loss of vision and a severe posterior headache, which are associated with posterior cerebral artery stroke. A noncontrast CT of the head rules out a hemorrhagic stroke. Middle cerebral artery stroke and vertebrobasilar stroke generally present with different symptoms, such as hemiparesis or facial drooping, and subarachnoid hemorrhage usually presents with sudden and severe headache and neck stiffness.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden loss of vision, accompanied by a severe headache, suggests a posterior cerebral artery stroke. The fact that a noncontrast CT of the head did not show evidence of hemorrhagic stroke also supports this diagnosis. Vertebrobasilar stroke would cause more widespread neurological deficits, such as altered consciousness or motor/sensory deficits, and subarachnoid hemorrhage would typically present with acute onset of severe headache and neck stiffness.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden loss of half of the visual field and severe posterior headache suggest a posterior cerebral artery stroke. There is no evidence of hemorrhagic stroke in the noncontrast CT scan, ruling out subarachnoid hemorrhage. The inability to recognize her niece suggests a neurological deficit beyond the middle cerebral artery, which rules out options A and B.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden loss of vision, half of the page, accompanied by severe posterior headache suggests posterior cerebral artery stroke. The inability to recognize her niece also supports this diagnosis. A noncontrast CT of head would not show evidence of a stroke within a few hours of the onset of symptoms. Subarachnoid hemorrhage would present with a sudden, severe headache and possible loss of consciousness. Middle cerebral artery stroke would present with weakness or numbness on one side of the body. Vertebrobasilar stroke would present with various signs of brainstem and cerebellar dysfunction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden loss of vision and severe posterior headache are indicative of a posterior cerebral artery stroke. The patient was also unable to recognize her niece, which could be a sign of a visual field defect. A noncontrast CT scan ruling out hemorrhage also supports a diagnosis of stroke rather than subarachnoid hemorrhage. The middle cerebral artery stroke would not typically present with posterior headache or visual symptoms restricted to one half of the page, while vertebrobasilar stroke typically presents with other neurologic symptoms such as ataxia, vertigo, or dysarthria.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a posterior cerebral artery stroke, which is commonly accompanied by a severe headache and visual disturbances. The noncontrast CT head rules out hemorrhagic stroke. The middle cerebral artery stroke will cause weakness on one side of the body while subarachnoid hemorrhage will present with a sudden severe headache. Vertebrobasilar stroke will cause multiple symptoms including visual and motor disturbances, but the severe posterior headache is more indicative of a posterior cerebral artery stroke.
